Quiz #1 You can write separate programs for each problem. (Advanced students: you are welcome to combine some of these into one program if you wish). Please turn in all your answers as a single PDF. For each problem, make sure to clearly show: Source Code Program Output Label each problem clearly to ensure easy grading. This quiz is open book, so you can reference your homework, the internet, our Discord channel, and our Google Drive materials as needed. Please Note: The "Challenge" part of the questions is optional and does not count towards your grade. It is for advanced students who want to attempt it for fun.

###### Problem #1: Name (10 points) 
Use a loop to write your name ten times. Show two different loop styles to accomplish this (so two examples, a and b ).

Quiz #1 You can write separate programs for each problem. (Advanced students: you are welcome to combine some of these into one program if you wish). Please turn in all your answers as a single PDF. For each problem, make sure to clearly show: Source Code Program Output Label each problem clearly to ensure easy grading. This quiz is open book, so you can reference your homework, the internet, our Discord channel, and our Google Drive materials as needed. Please Note: The "Challenge" part of the questions is optional and does not count towards your grade. It is for advanced students who want to attempt it for fun.

###### Problem #4:

Random (10 points)

- Print out a random number between 5 and 8 using the random function.
  printf("%d", num)
- Hint: Look at my "Random" class notes, specifically the Google Docs named z-Random and z- Randomexample , which show you how to get a random number within a range.

- Show two different ways to accomplish this:

- 1. One that includes 8 as a possible answer (inclusive of 8).

- 2. One that is non-inclusive of 8.
```c
#incluce <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <time.h>

int main (void) {

srand(time(null)); // seeds random generator with unix timecode

int min = 5;

int max = 8; 

int randomNumInc = (rand() % (max - min + 1)) + min;
int randomNumMaxExclusive = (rand() % (max - min)) + min;

printf("A random number from %d to %d: %d\n", min, max, randomNumInc)
 
 return 0;
}
```

#include <stdio.h>
int main(void)
{

    // Voltage (10 points)

    // Ask a user to enter a number and then:
    printf("\n");
    printf("Voltage Tester\n");

    for (;;)
    {
        double userVoltage;
        printf("Enter Voltage:\n");

        for (scanf("%lf", &userVoltage) != 1) // if scanf FAILS
        {
            ; // clear invalid input
            printf("Invalid Character.");
            printf("%*s"); // clear invalid input
            printf("Please enter a valid number:");
            printf("\n");
        }
       #include <stdio.h>

Quiz #1 You can write separate programs for each problem. (Advanced students: you are welcome to combine some of these into one program if you wish). Please turn in all your answers as a single PDF. For each problem, make sure to clearly show: Source Code Program Output Label each problem clearly to ensure easy grading. This quiz is open book, so you can reference your homework, the internet, our Discord channel, and our Google Drive materials as needed. Please Note: The "Challenge" part of the questions is optional and does not count towards your grade. It is for advanced students who want to attempt it for fun.

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void) {
printf("Voltage Tester (A7)\n");

    for (;;) {                                   // session loop
        double v;

        for (;;) {                               // inner guard
            printf("Enter Voltage:\n");
            if (scanf("%lf", &v) != 1) {
                printf("Invalid. Try again.\n");
                scanf("%*[^\n]"); scanf("%*c");
                continue;
            }
            break;
        }

        int band = (v <= 30) ? 0
                 : (v <= 59) ? 1
                 : (v  < 240) ? 2
                              : 3;

        switch (band) {
            case 0: printf("low voltage.\n"); break;
            case 1: printf("medium voltage.\n"); break;
            case 2: printf("high voltage.\n"); break;
            default: printf("electrocution!\n"); break;
        }

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void) {
printf("Voltage Tester (A7)\n");

    for (;;) {                                   // session loop
        double v;

        for (;;) {                               // inner guard
            printf("Enter Voltage:\n");
            if (scanf("%lf", &v) != 1) {
                printf("Invalid. Try again.\n");
                scanf("%*[^\n]"); scanf("%*c");
                continue;
            }
            break;
        }

        printf("Again? (y/n): ");
        char ans;
        if (scanf(" %c", &ans) != 1 || !(ans=='y' || ans=='Y')) break;
    }
    return 0;

}

###### Problem #6:

// Voltage (10 points)
double UserVoltage;
// Ask a user to enter a number and then:
printf("enter a voltage:")
scanf("%lf", userVoltage)
// If it's less than or equal to 30, tell them "low voltage."
if (userVoltage <= 30)
{
printf("low voltage")
} else if (userVoltage <= 59) {
// If it's between 31 and 59 (inclusive), tell them "medium voltage."
printf("medium voltage.")
} else if (userVoltage < 240) {
// If it's greater than or equal to 60 but less than 240, tell them "high voltage."
printf("high voltage.")
} else {
// If it's 240 or over, tell them "electrocution!"
printf("electrocution!")
}

Quiz #1 You can write separate programs for each problem. (Advanced students: you are welcome to combine some of these into one program if you wish). Please turn in all your answers as a single PDF. For each problem, make sure to clearly show: Source Code Program Output Label each problem clearly to ensure easy grading. This quiz is open book, so you can reference your homework, the internet, our Discord channel, and our Google Drive materials as needed. Please Note: The "Challenge" part of the questions is optional and does not count towards your grade. It is for advanced students who want to attempt it for fun.

###### Problem #1: Name (10 points)

Use a loop to write your name ten times. Show two different loop styles to accomplish this (so two examples, a and b ).

###### Problem #7: Namecount (10 points)

Redo Problem #1, but every time you print your name out, also print out the value of the loop counter. Do this five times for each loop style you used in Problem #1

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void)

{
int talley = 1
const char name[5] = "Trev";
for (int i = 0; i <= 5; i++)
{
printf("%s %d", name, talley);
tally++;
}
int count = 0;
while (count <= 5)
{
printf("%s %d", name, talley;
tally++;
count++;
}

    return 0;

}

Quiz #1 You can write separate programs for each problem. (Advanced students: you are welcome to combine some of these into one program if you wish). Please turn in all your answers as a single PDF. For each problem, make sure to clearly show: Source Code Program Output Label each problem clearly to ensure easy grading. This quiz is open book, so you can reference your homework, the internet, our Discord channel, and our Google Drive materials as needed. Please Note: The "Challenge" part of the questions is optional and does not count towards your grade. It is for advanced students who want to attempt it for fun.

###### Problem #2: Fifty (10 points)

Ask the user to enter a number and tell them if the number is greater than 50 or not. Challenge (Optional): Guard for valid input (i.e., make sure they enter a number and not string garbage).

###### Problem #8:

Fiftytally (10 points) Redo Problem #2, but this time put it in a loop that keeps asking for numbers until you enter a negative number. At that point, you'll exit the loop and tell them how many of their entered numbers were greater than 50. This problem requires you to use a loop and also keep a tally of the number of times the entered number is over 50.

#include <stdio.h>

int main(void)
{

    int userNum, tally;               // Variable to store user number

    do
    {
    printf("Enter a number:"); // Ask the user to enter a number
    while (scanf("%d", &userNum) != 1)
    {
        printf("Invalid input. Please enter a valid number: ");
        scanf("%*s"); // clear invalid input
        // then if: if the number is greater than 50 or not.
    };

    if (userNum > 50)
    {
        printf("%d is greater than 50!", userNum);
        tally++;
    }
    else if (userNum < 50)
    {
        printf("%d is less than 50!", userNum);
    }
    else
    {
        printf("%d is equal to 50!", userNum);
    }

} while (userNum > 0);
printf("%d", tally)
return 0;
}

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <time.h>

#define NUM_HORSES 4
#define INITIAL_BALANCE 200
#define BET_AMOUNT 10

int main(void)
{

    //   Recognize commands like:
    //   exacta 2 1 ,
    //   exactabox 3 2 ,
    //   trifecta 1 2 3 ,
    //   trifectabox 1 3 2 ,
    //   balance ,
    //   exit .
    //
    int exacta, exactabox, trifecta, trifectabox, balance, exit;

    balance = INITIAL_BALANCE;
    return 0;
}

EXACTA 1 3 : Betting that Horse #1 will finish first, and Horse #3 will finish second. 
 
 EXACTABOX 1 4 : Betting that Horse #1 and Horse #4 will finish in the top two positions, in any order. If the race result is 4 1 2 3 , you still win.
 
  TRIFECTA 1 3 2 : Betting that Horse #1 will finish first, Horse #3 second, and Horse #2 third, in that exact order. 
  
  TRIFECTABOX 1 4 2 : Betting that Horse #1, Horse #4, and Horse #2 will finish in the top three positions, in any order. If the race result is 1 2 4 3 , you still win. 
  
  
  Grading Criteria (25 points) 
  
User Input & String Menu:
  

   
Implement a string-based menu that uses string splitting to parse user bets. 
Crucially, this must be a string menu, not a numeric one. You should not be choosing a bet by number (e.g., "Enter 1 for Exacta"), but by typing the command (e.g., "exacta 1 2"). (
   
 Betting Logic Functions
   
   Write the following four functions (or methods for object-oriented languages): 
   
   Exacta :
   Takes a two-element array (or list for Python) of user picks, 
   and a four-element array of the winning sequence. 

if the exacta bet is won.
   Updates Balance
   Returns true  
   
 Exactabox : 
 Takes a two-element array (or list for Python) of user picks 
 and a four-element array of the winning sequence. 

if the exactaBox bet is won.
Update Balance
Returns true if the exacta box bet is won. 


Trifecta : 
Takes a three-element array (or list for Python) of user picks 
and a four-element array of the winning sequence. 

if the trifecta bet is won
Update Balance
Returns true . 

Trifectabox : 
Takes a three-element array (or list for Python) of user picks 
and a four-element array of the winning sequence;

if the trifecta box bet is won. 
Updates Balance;
Returns true (20 points) 


Before each bet is placed, 
you must run a new race and display the winning sequence to the user. 
Displaying the "Cheat": 
This is the "cheat." 
Example: 
The Cheat: 1 3 2 4 
bet> exacta 1 3 
This feature is crucial for both testing your code (allowing you to input winning bets easily) and for grading. (10 points) 


Race Simulation with ReadySetGo : 
Use the ReadySetGo function (for C) that I provide to simulate each race. 

Your program flow should be:

Get user input -> 
Run race -> 
Determine win/loss using the four betting functions. (20 points) 

Money Management: 
Start with a cash balance of $200 USD. 
Deduct the cost of each bet from the balance. 
Add the winnings to the balance when a bet is won. 
Provide a "balance" command/option to display the current USD balance. 

Implement your program logic within a loop so users can place multiple bets, run races, and check their balance continuously. 

Implement an "exit" command to terminate the program. After every bet, clearly inform the user if they won or lost and show their current updated balance. 

Demonstration Requirements 
To effectively show your program works, your submission output must clearly demonstrate the following scenarios, with your balance printed as specified:

1. balance Win an exacta bet 1
2. Lose an exacta bet 
3. Win an exacta box bet 
4. Lose an exacta box bet balance 
5. Win a trifecta bet Lose a trifecta bet 
6. Win a trifecta box bet 
7. Lose a trifecta box bet 
8. balance 
9. exactabox 2 2 2 (should give you an error) 
10. exit 

Ensure that horse selections for bets are unique 
(e.g., no exacta 1 1 or trifecta 3 3 4 ). 
Your program should handle or prevent such invalid inputs.

files.content:
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <time.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <ctype.h>

#define ROWS 10
#define COLS 10

void print_grid(int grid[ROWS][COLS], int generation)
{
    printf("Generation %d:\n", generation);

    for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++)
    {
        for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++)
        {
            printf("%c ", grid[row][col] ? 'X' : 'O');
        }
        printf("\n");
    }

    printf("\n");
}

int count_alive(int grid[ROWS][COLS])
{
    int aliveCount = 0;

    for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++)
        for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++)
            aliveCount += grid[row][col];

    return aliveCount;
}

static void to_lower_str(char *s)
{
    for (; *s; s++)
        *s = (char)tolower((unsigned char)*s);
}

int main(void)
{
    srand((unsigned int)time(NULL));

    int current_grid[ROWS][COLS];
    int next_grid[ROWS][COLS];

    int total_cells = ROWS * COLS;

    while (1)
    {
        /* Random initialization (new game round) */
        for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++)
            for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++)
                current_grid[row][col] = rand() % 2;

        /* Show Generation 0 before guessing */
        print_grid(current_grid, 0);

        int alive_initial = count_alive(current_grid);
        printf("Alive: %.1f%%\n\n", (alive_initial * 100.0) / total_cells);

        /* One-line input for iterations + guess, or exit */
        char line[200];
        int iterations = 0;
        char guess = '\0';

        while (1)
        {
            printf("Enter iterations and guess (A/D) on one line, or type exit: ");
            if (!fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin))
                return 0; /* EOF */

            /* trim newline */
            line[strcspn(line, "\n")] = '\0';

            char lower[200];
            strncpy(lower, line, sizeof(lower) - 1);
            lower[sizeof(lower) - 1] = '\0';
            to_lower_str(lower);

            if (strcmp(lower, "exit") == 0)
                return 0;

            int parsed = sscanf(line, "%d %c", &iterations, &guess);
            if (parsed == 2 && iterations >= 0)
            {
                guess = (char)toupper((unsigned char)guess);
                if (guess == 'A' || guess == 'D')
                    break;
            }

            printf("Invalid input. Example: 5 A   (or type exit)\n");
        }

        for (int generation = 1; generation <= iterations; generation++)
        {
            for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++)
            {
                for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++)
                {
                    int neighborCount = 0;

                    for (int dr = -1; dr <= 1; dr++)
                    {
                        for (int dc = -1; dc <= 1; dc++)
                        {
                            if (dr == 0 && dc == 0)
                                continue;

                            int neighborRow = (row + dr + ROWS) % ROWS;
                            int neighborCol = (col + dc + COLS) % COLS;

                            neighborCount += current_grid[neighborRow][neighborCol];
                        }
                    }

                    if (current_grid[row][col])
                        next_grid[row][col] = (neighborCount == 2 || neighborCount == 3);
                    else
                        next_grid[row][col] = (neighborCount == 3);
                }
            }

            /* Copy next generation into current */
            for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++)
                for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++)
                    current_grid[row][col] = next_grid[row][col];

            print_grid(current_grid, generation);
        }

        int alive_final = count_alive(current_grid);
        int dead_final = total_cells - alive_final;

        printf("Final counts after %d iterations:\n", iterations);
        printf("Alive (X): %d\n", alive_final);
        printf("Dead  (O): %d\n", dead_final);

        if (alive_final == dead_final)
            printf("It's a tie.\n");
        else if ((alive_final > dead_final && guess == 'A') ||
                 (dead_final > alive_final && guess == 'D'))
            printf("You were RIGHT.\n");
        else
            printf("You were WRONG.\n");

        printf("\n");
    }
}

session_log.session_title: C Course Complete Consolidation & GitHub Preparation
session_log.context: Consolidating entire C programming course (50_CSc) from scattered files across system into unified structure for GitHub portfolio
session_log.turning_point_prompt:
User Query: "Extract all C programming course content from /Users/trevabbott/bayFamilyVault/schoolMediaTrev/10_codeLibrary/C_++/50_CSc into compressed JSON. Include all .c/.h files with full content, all .md/.txt docs. Mark duplicates (files with 'copy' suffix, iterations like draft2/test2). Output valid JSON."

Context: User had 270 C source files scattered across assignments, with duplicates, multiple versions, and needed everything consolidated with Canvas course data for GitHub setup following dev-workflow-docs standards.

Breakthrough: Realized need to map Canvas assignments (REQUIREMENTS) to local files (SOLUTIONS), then use PDF submission timestamps as "last touch" to reconstruct Git history backwards.

commands_developed.purpose: Global code audit - find every code file on system
commands_developed.why: Need complete inventory before deduplication and organization

commands_developed.purpose: Filter to specific course files (270 files)
commands_developed.why: Narrow scope to relevant files for this consolidation
commands_developed.result: Complete map of all C course files

commands_developed.why: Need to extract C code from PDF submissions to verify completeness
Identify which assignment each PDF contains by reading actual code
commands_developed.discovery: PDFs labeled incorrectly - needed content verification

commands_developed.purpose: Parse all .c/.h files and build structured JSON
commands_developed.contains: All source code with full content, organized by assignment/problem/file

commands_developed.purpose: Parse Canvas HTML export and extract lessons/assignments
commands_developed.contains: 23 modules, 171 pages, 11 assignments with full descriptions

workflow_evolution.phase_1: Initial extraction - discovered local files were SOLUTIONS to Canvas REQUIREMENTS
workflow_evolution.phase_2: Cross-referencing - matched Canvas assignments to local implementations
workflow_evolution.phase_3: PDF hunt - found all missing submission PDFs in /code_audit/missing pdfs/
workflow_evolution.phase_4: Timeline reconstruction - used PDF timestamps as 'last touch' dates
workflow_evolution.phase_5: Git history inference - identified draft2/test2 as intermediate commits

key_discoveries: HW7 is actually a second draft of HW5 (bitcoin), not separate assignment
annotated-main.c.pdf is HW6/7 (File I/O with candy data)
Quiz 2 had 2 PDFs - original + annotated supplemental
All 270 files map to 12 assignments (CheckIn + 6 HW + 2 Quiz + Midterm + Final)

c_class_extracted.json.contains: All local C source code with full content

canvas_course_extracted.json.contains: Complete Canvas export - modules, pages, assignments

pdf_submission_map.json.contains: Mapping of all 42 PDF submissions to assignments

50_csc_complete_file_map.txt.contains: All 270 C course file paths from global audit

c_course_unified.json.status: FINAL OUTPUT - ready for GitHub agent
includes: Inferred Git commit history from timestamps

git_reconstruction_strategy.principle: Work backwards from PDF submissions (last touch) to source files (iterations)
git_reconstruction_strategy.timeline: PDF timestamp = final commit date for each assignment

branches.feature/arrays-conway: HW3 - Arrays and Conway's Game of Life

for_github_agent.instructions: This JSON contains EVERYTHING needed to set up c-intro-50-csc repo
includes: All source code paths and content
Inferred Git commit history with dates

assignments_inventory.name: Homework 3 - Arrays and Conway's Game of Life
Homework 6 - File I/O (Candy Data)
assignments_inventory.note: HW7 folder is actually draft2 of this assignment

git_reconstruction.commit_strategy: Work backwards from PDF timestamps, draft2/test2 = intermediate commits
